page.title: 18Ecology-surroundings of BSE
page.content: Because the area has been intensively farmed there has been considerable effect on the natural environment. This can be most obviously seen in the move to bigger fields to accommodate modern machinery and the resultant loss of hedgerows with their animal habitats and wild flowers. Another by-product of larger fields has been the loss of many footpaths which have been ploughed over and lost to public use except where ramblers' associations are active. Issues which have arisen in recent times with regard to pollution include the pollution of streams by nitrate fertilizers, the possible dangers for people and animals of aerial crop-spraying and the anti-social effects of stubble burning after the harvest.
